executive_summary: The Boxing Promoters industry has experienced robust growth for most of the five years to 2022, before being hit by the COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak. In 2020, the government imposed the closure of nonessential businesses, leading to the mass cancelation and postponement of many sports events, including boxing matches. However, the distribution of vaccines and the resumption of social events in 2021 have helped industry operators to recover most of the losses in 2021. Moreover, during the current period, two highest-grossing fights in boxing history took place, renewing interest in the sport itself and expanding revenue. Overall, IBISWorld estimates that industry revenue has increased at an annualized rate of 2.2% to $438.6 million over the five years to 2022, including an anticipated increase of 1.8% in 2022 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Operators coordinate and promote boxing events
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Operators in the Boxing Promoters industry coordinate and promote boxing events for rosters of athletes, assuming the vast majority of risk for organizing an event. Therefore, the industry is highly competitive, and operators compete with each other to obtain the most talented boxers possible through the most high-profile TV networks and entertainment venues.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Industry grew during the five-year period
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As consumers continued to spend on discretionary goods, including PPV events and sporting event tickets, the industry grew during the majority of the five-year period. In fact, the Boxing Promoters industry experienced impressive growth in line with the US economy, with particular growth in 2017 due to the match between Mayweather and Conor McGregor.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Revenue expected to grow over next five years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2027, IBISWorld estimates that revenue will grow at an annualized rate of 3.4% to total $519.0 million, including an increase of 1.8% in 2022 alone. Recovered economic conditions and increased consumer spending is expected to contribute to further revenue growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Profit expected to rise as operators use digital technology
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As operators rely more on digital technology to reduce costs, profit is also expected to rise.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Smaller operators may struggle with large contracts
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: At the same time, smaller industry operators will likely continue to struggle to obtain large industry contracts as such contracts often require operators to have a strong reputation with an impressive track record.

industry_definition: This industry includes individuals and licensed enterprises that organize, finance and promote all aspects of a boxing match, including all legal compliance, ticket sales and licensing needed to put on a fight. Companies are commonly independently owned and operated.

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: The rise of digital channels and sports betting has benefited the industry
COVID-19 had a substantial effect on the industry performance in 2020
Most operators organize events in local markets that do not command the global spotlight
The largest boxing promoters will maintain their leading positions in the next five years
Operators are expected to increasingly partner with streaming services
Consumer preferences will play an important role in the success of the industry
Rising digital trends and growing interest in sports betting have benefited the industry

market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers aged 30 to 49 are estimated to represent 40.9% of revenue. Consumers in this age category typically earn higher incomes and, consequently, are able to afford expensive pay-per-view fights, attend bars and other closed-circuit outlets and also pay to attend matches.

Consumers aged 18 to 29 are estimated to generate 28.5% of total revenue for the industry. These consumers are most likely to generate revenue through many industry services. Consumers in this age segment are more likely to be susceptible to marketing and, therefore, are the most important segment for sponsorship and other marketing campaigns.

Consumers aged 50 and over are estimated to comprise 30.6% of revenue. The outbreak of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic had a negative effect on this market segment in 2020 due to social distancing measures and health concerns among the oldest generation.

products_and_services.product_description: Operators in the Boxing Promoters industry typically assume the financial risk of staging boxing events. Once an event has been organized in tandem with various boxing commissions and organizations, the promoters then enter a distribution agreement and agree to promote and market the event. Revenue is generated from a combination of ticket sales, event management services, broadcast incentives and other deals.

Broadcast and media rights will generate an estimated 19.6% of the industry's revenue in 2022. Promoters market the event through major networks such as HBO or Showtime, as well as other means such as event sponsorship, promotional tie-ins, billboards and commercials. Fans can then purchase access to watch the match from home through their cable provider.

Event management services, such as VIP packages, meet and greet opportunities and merchandise sales are expected to remain a significant source of industry revenue. The industry also generates revenue from closed-circuit promotion, which includes revenue earned from bars and other outlets that are generally consolidated through the promoter and guarantee a fixed fee. Additionally, promoters generate revenue through sponsorships that include selling advertising space on the ring mat, posts and signage.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Higher levels of disposable income increase the likelihood of spending on discretionary entertainment, including live concerts and sporting events.
Demand for boxing and boxing promoters is also driven by general consumer attitudes toward the sport.
The public persona and reputation of an athlete can drive demand for boxing promotional services.

business_locations.location_description: The West comprises 19.3% of total industry establishments in 2022. The region holds 17.2% of the US population but also has many large cities that host major events. California is the single most concentrated state in the United States, with an estimated 13.8% of establishments.

The Mid-Atlantic region is estimated to account for 17.4% of total establishments in 2022. The region comprises 14.9% of the US population and includes major event centers such as New York, which is estimated to account for 9.6% of establishments.

The Southeast is estimated to comprise 22.0% of total industry establishments in 2022. The region accounts for 25.9% of the US population and, therefore, there is a large population base to host boxing events and generate promotional income. The most concentrated state in the region is Florida, which is estimated to account for 7.4% of industry establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Boxing promoters are required to receive licensing from their relevant state authority. Professional promoters often undergo more extensive licensing requirements.
Promoters need to complete requirements before fights such as notifying contests, organizing personnel, ensuring athlete licensing and discussing rules.
During the COVID-19 outbreak in 2020, many state governments imposed closure of non-essential businesses, affecting industry establishments.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Typically, promoters are required to attain a boxing promoter license from their respective state before operating; however, small-scale promoters often operate without a license in jurisdictions or organizations that may not require it.
Relationship management is critical to industry operators, and an extensive network of contacts is essential as a means of winning clients and sponsorships and as a way to attract spectators.

basis_points.basis_description: A moderate level of competition exists in the Boxing Promoters industry. Competition varies throughout the industry and is dependent on the services that each company can offer, what exclusive deals they provide and the relationships they have with other athletes and companies.

Establishments compete with each other based on the ability to market and advertise fights and athletes. Promoters holding relationships with key boxing organizations, major venues and premium cable networks are most likely to be successful.
The Boxing Promotion industry has experienced a low to moderate degree of external competition. Services provided by boxing promoters are typically specialized and target specific audiences.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 3 Companies Account for 66.6% of Revenue
concentration_points.concentration_description: In 2022, the three largest companies are estimated to account for 66.6% of industry revenue. Top Rank Inc., Golden Boy Promotions Inc. and Mayweather Promotion LLC are three leading industry players, which are sometimes referred to as the "Big Three" in the promotional boxing industry.

These three companies have achieved substantial recognition in the industry and have significant competitive advantages, enabling them to control the majority of the industry. These competitive advantages include contracts with high-profile athletes, partnerships with the top media platforms and detailed knowledge of the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: In 2022, wages are anticipated to account for 19.4% of industry revenue. Though most operators are nonemployers, they must include payments to boxing match participants as a portion of their wage costs.

Purchases include expenses related to the normal operation of industry establishments, such as technology and travel expenses. Considering the service-related nature of the industry, purchases' share of industry revenue tends to be relatively small.
In 2022, depreciation is expected to account for 1.9% of industry revenue. Most industry operators do not maintain facilities or significant amounts of equipment, so this expense is relatively low.
Industry operators use marketing to attract new clients. Marketing is expected to account for 3.5% of industry revenue in 2022.
Rent costs are related to expenses related to renting office spaces and similar facilities. Rent costs are anticipated to account for 4.9% of industry revenue in 2022.
Utility costs are expected to account for 0.8% of revenue in 2022.
Other costs represent the largest expense category for the industry. Boxing promoters incur large costs related to promoting their clients and boxing events.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The majority of industry operators do not maintain any property or equipment, a trend that is expected to persist over the next five years.

Due to the service-based nature of the industry, there are no major capital or machinery investment requirements. Basic maintenance and depreciation of office equipment contribute to the industry's primary purchases of small-scale capital and equipment.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Some mild volatility always exists within the industry as a result of changes in the number of fights per year and the talent involved in specific fights.

In 2020, revenue experienced a major decline due to the effects of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic, declining an estimated 47.0%. At the same time, the subsequent recovery of the industry in 2021 has contributed to additional volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Boxing Promoters industry operators are using any online-based platforms they can to reach their target and potential audiences.
Technological development for boxing promoters depends mainly on changes in current broadcast technologies to generate interest.
Arenas and event locations are increasingly being fitted with high-definition TVs, improved broadcasting systems and premium seating options to improve spectator experiences.

FAQs.question: How much does your company rely on successful advertising to stand out from the competition?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators invest significantly into marketing to stand out. Advertising is also very important to spread the word about upcoming matches.

FAQs.question: Is your revenue sensitive to changes in discretionary spending?
FAQs.answer: Since industry events are considered nonessentials, the industry is highly sensitive to discretionary spending levels.

FAQs.question: If your company benefits from population density, are you located in high traffic areas to increase your exposure?
FAQs.answer: Industry events hosted in major cities and other highly populated areas are more likely to draw a large crowd and boost revenue.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to use rental agreements to save on equipment expenses?
FAQs.answer: Many industry operators elect to rent rather than buy facilities and equipment to save funds. Nevertheless, buying these items generally leads to higher margins down the line.

FAQs.question: Has your company integrated web and mobile reservation and appointment systems to improve consumer accessibility?
FAQs.answer: Many of the industry's largest players rely heavily on their websites and mobile applications in order increase consumer accessibility.

FAQs.question: Have you established a strong internet presence through social media platforms to capture a larger audience?
FAQs.answer: The advent of social media has allowed many small industry operators to enter the industry, as promoters can easily spread the word about events through Facebook and Twitter.

FAQs.question: Are you up-to-date with legislative and regulatory changes that may allow your company to expand into new markets?
FAQs.answer: Many of the industry's largest players have in-house compliance teams that allow them to ensure that they are up-to-date with regulatory changes.

FAQs.question: Do you offer membership agreements, tickets or passes that may be subject to state or federal regulation?
FAQs.answer: While some industry operators offer membership agreements, these are not typical. Some operators may offer special promotions to consistent fans.

FAQs.question: Is your company's profit margin in step with major competitors'?
FAQs.answer: There are many small industry operators in this industry that weigh down the average industry profit margin. Meanwhile, larger operators may completely surpass the average profit margin.

FAQs.question: How can you maintain superior service while reducing operating costs?
FAQs.answer: Operators spend heavily on in-event labor costs, ensuring clients are well-taken care of.

FAQs.question: What locations is your company the most successful? Does it pay off to locate near areas where the sport is popular?
FAQs.answer: Promoters are most successful when offering events in regions where the sport will generate large live audiences.

FAQs.question: How loyal is your customer base? How do you ensure repeat customers? What percentage of revenue is devoted to retaining customers?
FAQs.answer: Smaller promoters will rely on attracting local and regional support rather than through major marquee events.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? Are you known for your reliability and performance? Having a good reputation
FAQs.answer: The most successful promoters have an established reputation in the sport for providing lucrative events that draw large audiences.

FAQs.question: How will you offset a decline in cable TV subscriptions? How can you cater to a younger, more on-demand market?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators have been increasingly working with streaming services.

FAQs.question: Do you keep track of trends regarding leisure time available to your customers? Does your revenue fall in line with such trends?
FAQs.answer: When time spent on leisure and sports increases, boxing promoters benefit by having a larger fan base with time to attend events. Time spent on leisure and sports is expected to decline in 2020, posing a potential threat to the industry.

FAQs.question: How closely do you monitor trends in per capita disposable income? Do you offer products for families with a wide range of disposable income levels?
FAQs.answer: When consumers have greater spending power, they are more likely to spend on pay-per-view programming and attend boxing matches. Per capita disposable income is expected to decline in 2022, posing a potential threat to the industry.
